para.caption: The Zend Engine 2
para.text:
In the Zend Engine 2 [ZE2], the object model has been largely rewritten. A short overview of the new functionality:
Objects are passed by handle, not by value.
Unified constructors and destructors
Private, public and protected variables and functions
Exceptions
Static class variables
Abstract classes and methods
Class constants
Although backwards compatibility has been tried to preserve, some changes are necessary. This document explains what has to be done in order to get source code written using the XP framework to run with the Zend Engine 2.

para.caption: Changes: Exception syntax (mandatory)
No single root class
para.text:
Due to the (in our opinion unnecessary) constraint of the Zend Engine 2 imposes on its exception mechanism (all exceptions must inherit the built-in exception class), we can no longer preserve the model of a single root class, Object.
To still be able to check for an instance of an XP class (in respect to stdClass or other built-in classes), an interface named Generic has been introduced. Both Object and Throwable (the root class of all exceptions) implement this interface, ensuring that toString, getClass, getClassName, hashCode and equals exist.
See also this CVS log message describing the mess. It also points to the archived messages concerning the discussion about this on the PHP developer's mailing list.

para.caption: Class name changes
para.text:
Due to the fact that PHP5 comes with a great number of built-in classes (but no namespaces concept), the Exception class had to be renamed to XPException and the Iterator interface's new name is now XPIterator.
When PHP5 is compiled with built-in SOAP support, the SOAPClient class also produces a name clash. It will also have to be renamed to something different.
